title: Welcome

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Workplace health and safety is essential for protecting the safety, health and wellbeing of our employees.

But it’s probably fair to say, that some people see it as just a regulatory burden… which is a shame, because it couldn’t be further from the truth.

Having a robust and effective health and safety programme means we reduce our risks and costs in many ways.

We suffer fewer injuries…

We reduce absence and turnover of our employees…

Increase our productivity as a result of a healthier, happier and more motivated workforce…

And we protect our reputation with fellow organisations and the public.

All businesses have a responsibility to ensure that health and safety arrangements are in place to look after their employees and anyone who could be harmed by their undertakings.

And there is a legal requirement to manage health and safety within the UK… and we are no exception.

Whether in the UK or elsewhere, we should see UK standards as best practice and maintain these as a minimum.

If there is a higher duty owed due to local regulations we should aim achieve this.

The approach taken should be proportionate to the complexity of the task and risks that are present.

For example, normal office tasks will require fewer control measures…

… than a machinery workshop using chemicals and power tools.

This digital package will help you learn more about implementing health and safety procedures…

… and provides advice on what you need to consider as a Leader, Manager, Supervisor, or if you have management responsibilities so you feel confident in discussing and applying the knowledge in your own workplace.

Morally it is the right thing to do and our ultimate aim must always be to ensure we are ‘Keeping our people safe’.

title: Welcome
body:
Welcome to this digital Health and Safety (H&S) Toolkit. The aim of this toolkit is to:
  • Improve and enhance your understanding of your core H&S responsibilities.
  • Ensure you recognise the importance of fulfilling your responsibilities to comply with regulations.
  • Show you where to find additional support and resources.

During this course the word ‘manager’ will be used to include Leaders, Managers, Supervisors, and all other roles that have management responsibilities.

The graphical menu will provide a short synopsis of each topic, helping you to choose the order in which you access the information. You will need to complete every topic, but when you have done this you will be able to access any of the topics as a reference resource.

The entire course should take you approximately 60 minutes to complete and at the end there will be a short validation to check your understanding.

title: Introduction
body:
As managers or those in positions of responsibility

it is essential you think about the types of plant or equipment that you or your employees may have to use, either as part of their job or occasionally.

It is important to consider this in proportion to the risk profile of the working area your employees work.

Lower risk office environments with DSE workstation equipment including electrical cables will normally have already been designed and provided for you and your employees use.

However potentially higher risk areas such as loading bays, workshops, manufacturing and catering facilities, etc. Will require you to think about what risks may occur and how these can be managed.

title: Plant & Equipment
instruction: Select the arrow to learn more about plant and equipment.

_items.body:
Hazard Exposure

Hazards associated with working near or on plant and machinery vary depending on the exact type used but can include exposure to:
  • Moving parts (e.g., risk of injuries from entanglement, friction, abrasion, cutting, severing, shearing, stabbing, puncturing, impact, crushing, drawing-in or trapping, etc.)
  • Energy (e.g., electrical, electromagnetic, etc.)
  • Heat or cold
  • Noise
  • Vibration
  • Radiation
  • Gas or liquid under pressure (e.g., injuries from injection or ejection by hydraulic systems, pneumatic systems, compressed air, paint sprayers, etc.)
  • Psychosocial hazards (e.g., stress, job content, work organisation, cognitive factors, etc.)

Risk Assessment

Those with management responsibility will need to ensure suitable and sufficient risk assessments are in place to control risks appropriately. It may be necessary to involve individuals with specialised or technical expertise (i.e. Your employees, engineer, health and safety team, manufacturer, etc.).

Those with management responsibility should ensure when selecting machinery or equipment that is correct for the task and environment it will be used in, again this may involve consultation with others.

Safeguards

During use of plant and machinery safeguards must remain in place – guarding, isolators, locking mechanisms, emergency off switches etc. Never allow the removal of any safeguards, even if their presence seems to make the job more difficult.

Ensure every static machine has been installed properly and is stable (usually fixed down) and the work area around the plant and machinery is kept clean and tidy, free from obstructions or slips and trips hazards, and well lit.

Safe system of work

Depending on the complexity of the plant and machinery there may be a need to develop a formal safe system of work (SSOW) which details the safe use and critical safety requirements to ensure safe use this should be completed in consultation with your employees and communicated as necessary.

Training

Adequate training should ensure that those who use the plant and machinery are competent to use it safely. This includes ensuring they have the correct skills, knowledge and experience – sometimes formal certification are needed, e.g. for chainsaw operators, grinding wheels, forklift trucks, mobile scaffold towers, banks-persons, etc. There may be a need to ensure refresher training is undertaken on a periodic basis.
Do not let unauthorised, unqualified or untrained people use plant and machinery – Some employees e.g. new starters, young people or those with disabilities, may be particularly at risk and need additional instruction, training and supervision.

Supervisors must also be properly trained and competent to be effective.

Evidence of training record and completion must be captured and available.

Maintenance

Plant and machinery will need to be maintained and fit to be used, this may be controlled by FM teams or similar however those with management responsibility should ensure that a system is in place for suitable maintenance by competent personnel and monitor accordingly.
In additional to routine maintenance consider what legal statutory inspections are required on plant and machinery such as lifting equipment, mechanical, electrical and pressure systems. Most statutory inspections once again will be controlled by FM teams or similar however those with management responsibility should ensure these are performed with evidence maintained on their behalf.
There should be a system that allows employees to report damaged or faulty equipment and consideration should be given to the development of a pre-use inspection checklist to assist in the process.

title: Occupational Health
body:
Health surveillance enables early identification of ill health and may be required by law if those you manage are exposed to noise, vibration, solvents, fumes, dust, biological agents and other substances hazardous to health, or work with compressed air.

Health surveillance is essential if there is an identifiable disease or adverse health effect which is related to an employees’ exposure to a health risk, and a risk assessment has identified as having a reasonable likelihood of occurring under the particular work conditions involved.

For high-hazard substances, the health surveillance programme may include statutory medical surveillance, involving a medical examination and/or tests. These must be performed by a doctor appointed by the Health and Safety Executive HSE.

When risk assessing thought must be given to health hazards and if required further guidance can be obtained through consultation with the Occupational Health and Health and Safety teams. Those with management responsibility should ensure that their employees understand any health hazards and if required report any negative effects to ensure employees are sufficiently protected.

title: Vibration
instruction: Select each image to read more about HAV and WBV

_items.title: Feedback
_items.body:
Hand-Arm Vibration (HAV)
  • Can be caused by operating hand-held power tools (e.g. hand-guided equipment, powered lawnmowers and hand-fed machines, such as pedestal grinders).
  • A painful and disabling condition that affects the nerves, blood vessels, muscles and joints of the hands and arms.
  • Causes tingling and numbness in the fingers, reduces grip strength and the sense of touch, and affects the blood circulation (vibration white finger, also known as VWF).

Whole Body Vibration (WBV)
  • Mainly affects drivers of vehicles used off-road, such as dumpers, excavators and agricultural tractors.
  • Can also affect drivers of vehicles used on paved surfaces, such as lift trucks, or on rails, such as gantry cranes.

Reducing Vibration Injuries
  • Those with management responsibility with their employees should consider if any tasks expose employees to the hazard of vibration. Consideration should be given to decide if it could be done another way?
  • Ensure machines and tools are regularly maintained to prevent vibration increasing (e.g. sharpness, condition of abrasive wheels, anti-vibration mounts).
  • A check on likely vibration levels before deciding on new tools or machines should be considered and the HSE has a vibration tool to assist. If required your health and safety team can offer advice if required.
  • Identify and assess hazardous machines, tools and processes (is there tingling or numbness in the hands after a few minutes’ use?).
  • Those with management responsibility must ensure their employees know how to report any concerns.

title: Introduction
body:
Those with management responsibility may require external, specialist help with a hazardous task or complex process.

However, it is important to recognise that the use of contractors does not mean that you can remove yourself from your usual health and safety responsibilities.

If you have a contractor working for you, then both you and the contractor will have duties under health and safety law. This also applies when a contractor employs subcontractors.

title: Working with Contractors
body: If you have a contractor working for you, then both you and the contractor will have duties under health and safety law.
instruction: Select each heading to learn more about working with contractors.

_items.title: Choosing a Supplier
_items.body: Select a suitable contractor, ensuring they have sufficient skills and knowledge to do the job safely and without risks to health and safety. Ensure you follow your local procurement processes when choosing a suitable contractor.

_items.title: Risk Assessment
_items.body:
The level of risk will depend on the nature of the job and whatever the risk, you will need to consider the health and safety implications.

Both you and the contractor should be aware of the findings. You should already have a risk assessment for the work activities of your own business, and the contractor must assess the risks for the contracted work. Both of you must then consider any risks from each other’s work, that could affect the health and safety of the workforce or anyone else.

_items.title: Before Work Starts
_items.body: Consider how the work will be managed and supervised before the work starts. Hold a pre-start meeting to ensure co-ordination and communication, and ensure that incorrect assumptions are not made. Remember, some of the risks in your workplace may not be obvious to the contractor, so highlight any specific risks, such as the presence of asbestos or noise.

_items.title: Monitor Work
_items.body: Decide what you need to do to manage and supervise the work of contractors, and agree the nature of the controls before work starts. You should then monitor their work, including their health and safety performance.

_items.title: Employees
_items.body: Ensure you provide information and instruction to your employees during the contracted work – paying close attention to any additional risks that will be introduced to your work area as a result of the work.

title: Construction (Design and Management)
body:
The Construction (Design and Management) Regulations (CDM) cover a broad range of construction activities such as building, civil engineering, construction work, demolition, site preparation, site clearance, renovation, decoration, installation, maintenance, and dismantling of structures.

A construction project is notifiable to the HSE if the construction work is expected to last longer than 30 working days and have more than 20 workers working at the same time at any point, or exceed 500 person days.

All reporting to the HSE must be managed through our contact. The health and safety team are available to provide support and guidance to achieve this.

title: CDM Regulations
body: Under the CDM Regulations, legal duties apply to duty holders.
instruction: Select each heading to learn more.

_items.title: Client
_items.body: The main duty for clients is to make sure their project is suitably managed, ensuring the health and safety of everyone who might be affected by the work, including members of the public. If you are responsible for a project this could be your role

_items.title: Principal Designer
_items.body: A designer appointed by the client to control the pre-construction phase on projects with more than one contractor. The principal designer’s main duty is to plan, manage, monitor and coordinate health and safety during this phase, when most design work is carried out.

_items.title: Designer
_items.body: The designer’s main duty is to eliminate, reduce or control foreseeable risks that may arise during construction work, or in the use and maintenance of the building once built. Designers work under the control of a principal designer on projects with more than one contractor.

_items.title: Principal Contractor
_items.body: A contractor appointed by the client to manage the construction phase on projects with more than one contractor. The principal contractor’s main duty is to plan, manage, monitor and coordinate health and safety during this phase, when all construction work takes place.

_items.title: Contractor
_items.body: Their main duty is to plan, manage and monitor the work under their control in a way that ensures the health and safety of anyone it might affect (including members of the public). Contractors work under the control of the principal contractor on projects with more than one contractor.

title: Introduction
body: Those with managerial responsibilities, at all levels, need to understand the health and safety risks in their part of the organisation and give proportionate attention to each of them. This means providing welfare facilities and a working environment that’s healthy and safe for everyone, including those with disabilities and those that are more vulnerable e.g. pregnant employee, younger person/apprentices.

title: Welfare
body: Select the arrow to read more on employee welfare.

_items.body:
Welfare Facilities

As a manager you should be aware that an employer must provide:
  • A suitable and sufficient number of toilets and basins (with soap and towels or a hand-dryer).
  • Toilets must adhere to DPA and building regulations for accessible facilities.
  • Drinking water.
  • A place to store clothing (and somewhere to change if special clothing is worn for work).
  • Somewhere for employees to rest and eat meals.

Healthy Working Environment

The workplace should:
  • Be clean with appropriate waste containers.
  • Have a reasonable working temperature (usually at least 16°C, or 13°C for strenuous work, unless other laws require lower temperatures).
  • Have good ventilation (fresh, clean air drawn from the outside or a ventilation system).
  • Provide lighting suitable and sufficient for the work being carried out.
  • Have the right amount of space and seating, with suitable workstations.
Most of these elements will be checked and maintained by your local facilities management, but as the person with management responsibilities you should be satisfied these factors are adequate and suitable for your employees.

Safe Workplace

To keep a workplace safe, you must:
  • Maintain your premises and work equipment.
  • Keep floors and traffic routes free of obstructions.
  • Ensure any transparent (e.g. glass) doors or walls are protected or made of safety material.
Some of these things will be by design, but as a manager you too have responsibility to maintain and look after your working areas to keep them safe.

title: Toilets and Washing Facilities
instruction: Select each image to read more about toilets and washing facilities.

_items.title: Feedback
_items.body: As a manager you should ensure any other premises where your team member’s work meets welfare requirements. It is important that you are aware that employers must ensure there are enough toilets and washbasins for those expected to use them. Provision must be made for any workers with a disability to enable them to have access to facilities that are, if necessary adjusted for their use.

_items.title: Feedback
_items.body: The facilities should ideally have tiled walls and floors (or be covered in suitable waterproof material) to make them easier to clean and should be well lit and ventilated. Ensure a supply of toilet paper and, for female employees, somewhere to dispose of sanitary items. As a manager if you find facilities are not adequate you should contact the facilities management.

_items.title: Feedback
_items.body: The basins should have hot and cold running water and soap or another washing agent. They should be large enough to wash the hands and forearms, if necessary, and a way of drying hands, such as paper towels or a hot-air dryer. If a facility does not have running water and alternatives are not provided you should not allow your employees to work in this environment.

_items.title: Feedback
_items.body: Showers and changing areas should be provided for employees involved in particularly strenuous or dirty work. As a manager you should determine whether showers and changing areas are necessary for your employees.

title: Temporary Worksites
body:
On temporary worksites those with management responsibilities should be aware that employers should provide flushing toilets and running toilets so far as reasonably practicable. If this is not possible managers should ensure that the employer have provided alternatives such as chemical toilets and water containers.

Using public toilets and washing facilities should be a last resort only, and not because they are a cheaper option. This would not be acceptable if it is possible to provide facilities on-site, as someone with managerial responsibilities you should not allow your employees to work in these circumstances.

title: Display Screen Equipment (DSE)
instruction: Select each image to find out more.

_items.title: What are the health effects?
_items.body: Display Screen Equipment (DSE) based work can potentially have serious effects on health both in the work place and when working from home. DSE users can experience a range of physical and psychological health problems including eyestrain, blurred vision, headaches, and musculoskeletal problems such as work-related upper limb disorders (WRULD).

_items.title: What causes this?
_items.body: Problems are usually caused by a combination of badly designed jobs, equipment or the work environment. However, most of these problems are preventable by paying attention to the way in which work is organised, and providing appropriate equipment and workplaces.

_items.title: What do I have to do?
_items.body:
As someone with management responsibilities, there are several simple practical steps that you can take to prevent these injuries to your team members.
Ensure your employees who use DSE for a significant part of their normal work period undertake the required DSE assessments to ensure any concerns can be rectified and that training is also completed and the principles are followed.
If any concerns are raised then signpost employees to the appropriate stakeholders to rectify any concerns. This could be through occupational health, in-house DSE assessors, IT, etc.

_items.title: How should I do this?
_items.body:
• Remind employees to have their eyes tested on a regular bases your organisation will have a scheme in place for this.
  • If employees use ‘hot-desking’, they will still need to check their workstation and adjust it to their requirements.

title: Slip and Trips
instruction: Play the video to learn more about preventing slips and trips.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Slips and trips are the most common cause of injury at work on average causing over a third of all serious injuries.

They can also lead to other accidents, such as falls from height or into machinery...

…and account for half of all reported injuries to members of the public, in workplaces such as hospitals, shops and restaurants.

Most slips occur when floors become wet or contaminated, by food for example, which can easily happen in kitchens or washing facilities, or when cleaning is taking place.

Trips are usually due to poor housekeeping, such as trailing cables, blocked traffic routes, insufficient lighting or uneven floors.

Those with management responsibility may have limited control over the design of their work area however they can help reduce the risk of slips and trips.
To help prevent these accidents managers need to think about what might cause slips or trips in their own workplace and decide if they are doing enough to prevent them.
Once the risks have been identified, controls must be put in place.

This should include preventing floors from getting wet or contaminated in the first place…

Encourage good housekeeping by your employees and report concerns to you…

Encourage your employees to look for defects in a surface, such as loose finishing, holes, cracks, worn rugs and mats, or spillages or poor lighting and report them through the appropriate route…

Ensure workers wear footwear that is suitable for the environment they are working in…

Ensure appropriate pedestrian routes are used by employee’s members and make sure you do too!

Last but by no means least, monitor your workplace to ensure best practice guidelines are being followed by everyone.

title: Workplace Transport
body: Select the arrow to read more on employee welfare.

_items.body:
When people and vehicles operate together, there is the potential for serious accidents.

Most transport-related accidents involve people being injured as a result of:
  • Being hit or run over by moving vehicles
  • Being struck by objects falling from vehicles
  • Falling from vehicles while loading or unloading
  • Vehicles overturning.

General Considerations

  • There is a general requirement that risk assessments should be carried out in order to assess the risks on your sites/vehicles and appropriate control measures put in place in accordance with that assessment.
  • The only truly effective solution is to keep vehicles and pedestrians entirely separate and make sure that they can’t operate in the same space at the same time. This can be done by physically separating them with barriers, or by timetabling vehicle and pedestrian work at different times.
  • If people do work where there are vehicles, then physical separation by barriers is better than having marked walkways – and well-marked walkways are far better than letting people choose for themselves.
  • In all cases, you can reduce the risk of collision by putting up signs and warnings in appropriate places, and training people to take notice of them. It’s no good having a line to mark a walkway if people don’t know which side of the line means ‘safe’.
  • If you and your employees work in an office environment, don’t think this isn’t about you. Lots of people get injured in car parks or on approaches to office buildings because they’re often off public roads and think they’re safe – they’re not.

Safe Sites

As a manager, you’ll need to make sure that vehicle risks in the areas you’re responsible for are managed effectively. Ask yourself the following questions:
  • What vehicles are operating and what are they doing?
  • In particular consider:
    • reversing
    • loading/unloading
    • tipping
    • cleaning
    • maintenance and repair
    • stability
    • parking, coupling and uncoupling
    • are the drivers trained and experienced on the vehicles they operate
Remember to think about less frequent tasks, such as waste skip changes.
  • Make sure you consider delivery drivers too who won’t be familiar with your workplace as they may particularly vulnerable.

Safe Vehicles

Those with management responsibility should consider the vehicles that their employees use:
  • Are vehicles in good repair and maintained, particularly the braking system, steering, tyres, lights, mirrors and specific safety systems.
  • Can the need for people to climb onto vehicles where possible be removed for example, by providing gauges and controls that are accessible from ground level?
  • Can you reduce the risk of falling when people have to climb onto a vehicle or trailer by providing well-constructed ladders, non-slip walkways and guard rails if possible? Are the employees using seat belts where required e.g. forklift trucks

Safe Drivers

Are your Drivers:
  • Trained, competent and authorised to use vehicles
  • Is refresher training provided?
  • Ensure all drivers are supervised (including those visiting the site) so far as reasonably practicable.
  • As a manager it is your responsibility to consider whether there is an easier, safer way of doing a job to reduce risks, you should consider involving your employees to assist you.

title: Introduction
body: There are numerous potential hazards in the workplace that could pose a risk to a person’s health, safety and wellbeing in the workplace.

title: COSHH Overview
body:
Chemical and hazardous substances can cause you injury or ill health. They can be found in the home and work – examples include adhesives, paints, cleaning agents, fumes from soldering and welding, grain dust and bacteria.

Effects from hazardous substances can range from mild eye irritation to chronic lung disease or even death, with the routes of entry to the body being ingestion, absorption, inhalation or injection.

Some substances are more harmful than others:
  • Some will harm you quickly
  • Some require large doses before they cause harm
  • Some may take years of exposure before any effects are seen.

Using chemicals or other hazardous substances at work may put employee’s health at risk and employers are required to control exposure to hazardous substances to prevent ill health. The aim is to protect both employees and others who may be exposed by complying with COSHH (Control of Substances Hazardous to Health) regulations.

title: Asbestos
body:
About 125 million people in the world are exposed to asbestos at the workplace according to the WHO.

In the UK thousands of commercial, industrial, residential, school and public buildings built or refurbished before 2000 are likely to contain asbestos containing materials (ACMs).

The wide use of asbestos was prohibited in the UK however regulations are less rigorous internationally.

Employees engaging in maintenance, repair, refurbishment, alteration or demolition activities could be exposed to asbestos fibres which can be released from asbestos containing materials such as roofing sheets, ceiling tiles, pipe insulation or lagging.

Anyone working with or near asbestos must be suitably trained and competent to undertake this type work.
instruction: Select each heading to learn more about asbestos.

_items.title: What are the health concerns?
_items.body:
Inhaling air containing asbestos fibres can lead to asbestos-related diseases, such as asbestosis, mesothelioma and lung cancer.

These diseases can take from 15 to 60 years to develop and can prove fatal.

_items.title: What do I need to know?
_items.body:
Those with management responsibilities need to know:
  • Asbestos is only dangerous when disturbed - removing it can be more dangerous than leaving it in place and managing it.
  • Not all asbestos materials present the same risk - the measures that need to be taken for controlling the risks from materials such as pipe insulation are different from those needed in relation to asbestos cement.
  • If you are unsure if certain materials contain asbestos, you should presume they do and treat them as such.
  • Your duty to manage is all about putting in place the practical steps necessary to protect maintenance workers and others from the risk of exposure to asbestos fibres - it is not about removing all asbestos.
  • If work is required, ensure you provide information to others, such as building contractors, who might disturb any asbestos present, so they can put in place appropriate controls while the work is being done.

If you suspect you have come across asbestos please contact the health and safety team for further support and guidance.

Further information can be found by accessing the internal asbestos awareness package.

title: Driving

Health and safety law apply to work activities on the road, in the same way as it does to all work activities, and you need to manage the risks with your employees.

Promoting sound health and safety driving practices may well spill over into private driving, and could reduce the chances of employees being injured in a crash whilst away from work.
  • Consider if employees are authorised to drive on company business and do they have the correct license and insurance for the vehicle to be used.
  • If driving is more operational then employees will be required to undertake additional training.
  • Consider if oversees driving is required and how employees are made aware of local rules and customs.
  • Those with management responsibilities need to be aware of their Organisation’s driving policy to ensure their employees understand their responsibilities.

title: Radiation
instruction: Select the arrow to learn about radiation.

_items.body:
Ionising Radiation

Radiation is generally classed as either ‘ionising’ or ‘non-ionising’. Sources of ionising radiation i.e. radioactive substances, instruments and equipment capable of emitting radiation, must only be used if there is no safer alternative. Use of ionising radiation must be justified.

Risks associated with use of ionising radiation and radioactive substances must be managed in accordance with legal requirements and management control principles.
If use of ionising radiation cannot be avoided and is justified, exposure to ionising radiations must be restricted in accordance with “as low as reasonably practicable” (ALARP). This is achieved by an assessment of the risk of harm to individuals’ health from exposure to radiation. If an unacceptable level of risk is identified, measures must be put in place which minimise the risk in line with the ALARP principle.

Ionising radiation includes X-rays, gamma rays and particulate radiation (alpha, beta and neutron radiation) produced from X-ray sets or radioactive substances. They are typically used in medical exposures, industrial radiography equipment and gauges used for process control, but may also be produced from naturally occurring radioactive substances, including radon gas.

Our organisation has appointed external competent advice from a radiation protection adviser (RPA) - this is a legal requirement when working with ionising radiation. Additionally our RPA offers internal training regarding ionising radiation please review your internal intranet for more information.

The health and safety team act as Radiation Protection Officer (RPO) and assist in radiation safety and compliance matters.

Those with management responsibility must identify all sources of ionising radiation that their employees could be exposed to including radon gas. This is naturally occurring and may be present in your workplace, even if you don’t do any other work with radiation.

Ensure appropriate shielding and personal protective equipment is used to reduce exposure when working with ionising radiation.

Non-ionising Radiations

These include radio frequency and microwaves, for example from welding practices and some communications transmitters; infra-red, such as very hot, glowing sources in glass and metal production;
Ultraviolet (UV) rays like welding or the sun visible radiation from high-intensity light sources such as lasers.

Microwaves and radio frequencies can cause heating of any exposed part of the body; infra-red rays can cause skin burns and cataracts and UV light can cause skin burns, skin cancer, and conjunctivitis and arc eye. Lasers can cause permanent, severe damage to the eye and skin.

Those in management need to consider all forms of non-ionising radiation and risk assess to determine if significant harm could be caused to their employees or others affected by their undertakings. Please be aware that managers will need to risk assess those with medical implants if working with electrical magnetic frequency.

title: Working from Height
body:
The Working at Height Regulations place an obligation on employers to ensure, so far as reasonably practicable, that their employees do not require to work at height. It is only if this cannot be avoided that the other considerations come into play.

If the work you and your employees are responsible for includes working at height, you need to make sure that:
  • It’s properly planned and organised
  • Your employees are competent
  • The risks have been assessed from working at height and controls put in place to protect employees and others (including the provision of appropriate training, suitable and sufficient equipment and protection from falling objects).
  • Ensure the risks from fragile surfaces have been considered and equipment for working at height is properly inspected and maintained.

Falls from height remain the single biggest cause of workplace deaths and are one of the main causes of major injury. Common cases include falls from ladders and through fragile surfaces.

The main causes of falls from height are:
  • Failing to recognise the risk i.e.an opening in a floor or a hole in the ground
  • Not providing a safe system of work and making sure it’s followed
  • Not providing adequate information, training, instruction or supervision
  • Not using equipment properly

Remember to ensure employees avoid working at height wherever possible. If they can’t avoid it:
  • use work equipment or other measures to prevent falls
  • use work equipment or other measures to minimise the distance and consequences of a fall.

title: Working at Height: Control Measures
body: Ensure all work is properly planned, supervised and carried out by competent people with the skills, knowledge and experience. Workers must use the right type of equipment for working at height and take a sensible approach when considering precautions.
instruction: Select each heading to see the control measures.

_items.title: Collective vs. Personal Protection
_items.body:
For each step, always consider measures that protect everyone at risk (collective protection) before measures that only protect the individual (personal protection).

Collective protection is equipment that does not require the person working at height to act for it to be effective. Examples are permanent or temporary guardrails, scissor lifts and tower scaffolds.

Personal protection is equipment that requires the individual to act for it to be effective. An example is putting on a safety harness correctly and connecting it, with an energy-absorbing lanyard, to a suitable anchor point.

When working at height cannot be avoided ensure consideration is given to emergency evacuation and rescue procedures.

title: Confined Spaces
instruction: Select the arrow to learn about confined spaces.

_items.body:
A confined space is one which is both enclosed, or largely enclosed, where there is a risk of death or serious injury from hazardous substances or dangerous conditions. This includes situations where there is a reasonable risk to workers of fire, explosion, and loss of consciousness, asphyxiation or drowning.

It may be small and restrictive for the worker, or can be far larger, such as a grain storage silo.

What are the hazards?

Working in a confined space is dangerous because of the risks from noxious fumes, reduced oxygen levels, or a risk of fire and explosions.

Other dangers may include flooding/drowning, loss of consciousness or asphyxiation from some other source, such as dust, grain or other contaminant.

What do I have to do?

Those with management responsibility should wherever possible avoid carrying out tasks in confined spaces. If this is not possible then you must assess the risks and with your employees plan how you will control those risks.

For example:
  • If there are noxious fumes consider how these can be ventilated or removed.
  • If there is a risk of liquids or gases flooding in, establish whether the valves can be locked shut.
  • If someone is going into a confined space and there is not enough oxygen to breathe properly, provide breathing apparatus or ventilate the space before entering.


You should have emergency arrangements where necessary. If someone is working in a confined space, think about the following:
  • How will you know they are OK and have not been overcome by fumes?
  • How will you get them out if they are overcome?
  • Ensure you and your employees are competent to perform the tasks that are required.

title: Electricity
body:
The main type of harm from electricity is electric shock, caused by coming into direct contact with an electrical conductor, such as the bare wires of an appliance while it’s live.

You can also be injured as a consequence of an electric shock: for example, if you get a shock while changing a light bulb, you could fall off your ladder. Electricity can also cause electrical burns and fire.

Most deaths and injuries from electricity are due to:
  • using poorly maintained electrical equipment
  • working near overhead power lines
  • contact with underground power cables during excavation work
  • working on or near domestic electricity supplies
  • use of unsuitable electrical equipment in explosive atmospheres, such as in car paint spraying booths.

Most of these could have been avoided by careful planning and relatively straightforward precautions.

title: H&S Legislation
body: As a manager, you need to assess ‘reasonably foreseeable’ risks and  put in place control measures to reduce the risks so far as is reasonably practicable.

_items.title: Reasonable foreseeability
_items.body:
The law requires you and your employers to manage reasonably foreseeable risks. This essentially means those risks that would be recognisable to a reasonable person or someone competent within your industry. For example, if you see a trailing cable across a doorway you know that there’s a high risk that someone will trip over it. Any such risk requires to be ‘reasonably foreseeable’ as the law recognises that it would be unfair to employers if they were expected to manage risks that could not have been identified or understood prior to an accident or incident occurring.

Select the arrow to learn more.

_items.title: Reasonable practicability
_items.body: The law imposes an obligation on employers to reduce risks to as low as reasonably practicable. This requires an assessment of the amount of effort and resources that should reasonably be applied to reduce the risk. An employer must balance the cost – in terms of time, effort, money or inconvenience –with the benefits to be gained from the associated risk control measure. If the cost to be incurred is grossly disproportionate to the benefits of the risk reduction measure, then it’s not ‘reasonably practicable’ to proceed.

_items.title: Common knowledge
_items.body: Managers are expected to foresee what the average person in the street would have foreseen, as that information is common knowledge. For example, if the public would have known that working on a roof in a gale without anything to stop a fall was dangerous, then so should you. This would be regarded as a reasonably foreseeable risk.

_items.title: Industry knowledge
_items.body: Employers and managers are expected to have industry specific knowledge so if a risk is well known within your industry then it is likely to be regarded as a reasonably foreseeable risk for your organisation and should be identified as such within your risk assessment. This applies even if this risk would be outside common or public knowledge as your organisation is expected to have the same level of background knowledge as other companies working in a similar industry. For example, if a company was using a chemical and didn’t realise how dangerous it was, but the rest of the industry had realised for years, and had introduced control measures or had replaced it with an alternative, your organisation wouldn’t be able to argue against reasonable foreseeability.

_items.title: Expert knowledge
_items.body: If knowledge of a risk is limited to those with expert or specialist knowledge (rather than generally known within the industry) then only experts would be expected to identify or manage these risks as they would not be reasonably foreseeable to others within the industry. For example, a research chemist would quite reasonably be expected to understand all the different properties of the substances they were handling, even if some risks were peculiar to the substance in very specific circumstances, beyond normal use.

_items.title: Summary
_items.body: Your organisation must be able to demonstrate reasonable foreseeability of significant risks covered by tests 1 and 2 but they would rarely face an expectation under test 3, unless they were an expert. Consider the jobs you and your employees do at work that give rise to reasonably foreseeable concerns. Those are the ones you need to act on.

_items.body:
There are various hazards which could pose a risk to a person’s health, safety and wellbeing and there is a requirement under law to conduct a suitable and sufficient risk assessment.

The hazards could include issues such as work equipment, chemicals, radiation, biological, fire, electricity, housekeeping, manual handling, DSE (ergonomics), lone working, vulnerable persons, slips, trips and falls, working at height, driving, travel (including internationally) and stress.

What is a risk assessment?

A risk assessment is nothing more than a careful examination of what in your work or activities could course injury or illness and how likely someone could be harmed and how seriously. You must identify those hazards, assess the level of risk (e.g. how likely is it that someone might be harmed? How serious is this likely to be) and then weigh up whether there are enough controls or more should be done to prevent harm? The aim is to make sure that no one gets hurt or becomes ill.

The level of detail in a risk assessment should be proportionate to the risk and appropriate to the nature of the work.

Your risk assessment should only include what you could reasonably be expected to know – you are not expected to anticipate unforeseeable risks.

There are various hazards which could pose a risk to a person’s health, safety and wellbeing and there is a requirement under law to conduct a suitable and sufficient risk assessment.

Managers help drive the risk assessment process and can manage the process by engaging others within their teams to complete the risk assessments on their behalf.

If advice is required then please consult with your health and safety team.

When should you use a risk assessment?

Both the Health and Safety at Work Act and the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations require that risk assessments are carried out.

The law states that a risk assessment must be ‘suitable and sufficient’, but what does that mean?

What should it include?

A risk assessment should consider who might be affected and the number of people who could be involved. Where possible, you should involve your workers or their representatives in the process.

You should identify reasonably foreseeable hazards within your workplace and assess the level of risks posed. The level of detail should be proportionate to the risk and the nature of the work.

Your assessment should only include what you could reasonably be expected to know – you are not expected to anticipate unforeseeable risks.

Controls

After assessing the risks, a decision can be made about preventative and protective control measures. These may only be small changes or may require more time and effort, but they should minimise the risk as far as reasonably practicable.

This means balancing the level of risk against the measures needed, to control the real risk in terms of money, time or trouble. You do not need to take action if it would be grossly disproportionate to the level of risk.

The legal requirement is ‘suitable and sufficient’, for a risk assessment to meet this requirement it should show that the following steps below have been taken:
  • Identification of the hazards.
  • Decide who might be harmed and how.
  • Evaluate the risks and decide on precautions.
  • Record your findings and implement them.
  • Review your risk assessment and update if necessary.

Consider Your Employees

  • Are you and your employees competent in performing risk assessments? If you need to brush up on what is expected of you when conducting a risk assessment the health and safety team have developed some hazard identification and risk assessment training packages and an aide memoir of hazards to consider. These are located on your IT systems.
  • As a manager you need to be aware of the risk assessments for your employees and any other risk assessments that are pertinent to the tasks they complete.
  • As a manager you should review to decide if controls identified have been implemented.
  • Do you know if the risk assessments have been communicated to your employees?
  • Are the risk assessment’s regularly reviewed? Few workplaces stay the same. Sooner or later you may bring in new equipment, substances or procedures that could lead to new hazards. It makes sense therefore to review what your employees are doing on an ongoing basis and manage the update of risk assessments accordingly.
  • The legal requirement is “suitable and sufficient” as described earlier. However there is no legal template for risk assessments but it is recommended that the corporate risk assessment is used. This is located on your IT systems.

title: Sensible and Proportionate
body:
"There is a need for a sensible and proportionate approach to risk management, in short, a balanced approach – this means ensuring that paperwork is proportionate, does not get in the way of doing the job, and it certainly does not mean risk elimination at all costs."

Judith Hackitt, Former HSE Chair

title: Multi-occupancy
body:
Where we share workplaces (whether on a temporary or permanent basis), there is a need to co-operate to enable compliance with other employers respective health and safety obligations.

As a manager you must take all reasonable steps to co-ordinate the measures adopted to fulfil those obligations. For example:
  • Are you aware of what to do in an emergency?
  • What is the fire evacuation process?
  • Where is the first aid point?
  • Have you and your team been inducted to the workplace?

You may need to tell other employers about any risks the work activities you manage could present to employees, both on- and off-site.

Further details can be found within the Health and Safety Policy.

title: Consulting your Employees
instruction: Select each card to see more on employee consultation.

_items.body: Organisations where employees are involved in taking decisions about health and safety are safer and healthier. Collaboration with your employees helps you to manage health and safety in a practical way.

Employees can help you spot workplace risks, ensure health and safety controls are practical, increase the level of commitment to working in a safe and healthy way, and provide feedback on the effectiveness of your health and safety arrangements and control measures.

In workplaces where a trade union is recognised, collaboration will be through union representatives. In non-unionised workplaces, you can consult either directly or through other elected representatives. Representatives’ main role is to talk to their employer about issues affecting the health and safety of the employees they represent. You should ensure that representatives receive paid time off during normal working hours, so they can carry out their duties. They should also receive suitable training and access to any facilities needed to help them in their role.

Consultation should involve listening to employees and taking account of what they say, before making decisions. Provide information to allow employees and their representatives full and effective participation in the consultation process, including the risks arising from their work, proposals to manage and/or control these risks, what to do if employees are exposed to a risk and the best ways of providing information and training.

Within your organisation more details of representatives will be available on the intranet. Those with management responsibilities should make themselves aware of and engage with the appropriate teams.

title: Training and Competence
body:
It is a legal requirement to provide health and safety information, instruction and training. This helps to reduce the risk of you and your employees becoming injured or made ill at work.

It helps to promote a positive safety culture, where safe and healthy working becomes second nature to everyone and enables us to meet our legal duties.

_items.title: What do we mean by training?
_items.body:
Training means helping people to learn how to do something, telling people what they should or (often as important) should not do, or simply giving them information.

Training isn’t just about formal ‘classroom’ courses and obtaining ‘tickets’ (certificates) to work.

_items.title: Effective Training
_items.body:
Effective training will:
  • Contribute towards making your employees competent in health and safety.
  • Help your teams to avoid the distress that accidents and ill health cause.
  • Help you avoid unplanned financial implications.
  • Increase productivity – healthier, happier and more motivated employees.
  • Enable projects to achieve their aims more efficiently and effectively.

_items.title: Training Basics
_items.body:
As a minimum your employees should receive training on induction, basic fire safety, manual handling and Display Screen Equipment (DSE) basics.

There may be additional specific types of training required that have been highlighted within your risk assessments or that you are aware of. For example, asbestos awareness, forklift truck training, radiation protection advisor, abrasive wheel operator course.

People’s skills may need updating by refresher training and normally this would be recommended by the course provider and detailed on any certificates obtained.

_items.title: Your Employees
_items.body: Those with management responsibilities should be aware if their employees have had the relevant training for the tasks they are to perform and that it is still current. It would be prudent to maintain evidence of all training to assist in the management of competency levels within your Employees.

title: Module 6: Personal Protective Equipment and Signage
displayTitle: Module 6: Personal Protective Equipment and Signage

title: Introduction
body:
Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is equipment that will protect the user against health or safety risks. It can include safety helmets and hard hats, gloves, eye protection, high-visibility clothing, safety footwear and safety harnesses.

Safety signs are used if there is a significant risk that can't be avoided or controlled in any other way, such as through safe systems of work or controls. There is no need to provide safety signage if they don't help reduce the risk

title: Choosing PPE
body:
To ensure the right Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is chosen, consider the different hazards your employees or you may encounter. Identify the PPE that will provide adequate protection against them, remembering this may be different for each job.

PPE should not be considered as the first-choice control measure. PPE should be used as a last resort. If the risks to health and safety cannot be adequately controlled in other ways then PPE must be supplied.

The Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations require that PPE is:
    Properly assessed before use to make sure it is fit for purpose.

    Maintained and stored properly.

    Provided with instructions on how to use it safely.

    Used correctly by employees.

_items.title: Supplier Advice
_items.body:
Ask your supplier for advice on the types of PPE available and their suitability for different tasks.

Select the arrow to learn more.

_items.title: Training and Supervision
_items.body: Employers must make sure employees are trained on the use of PPE – when and why it is needed; how to maintain, repair or replace it; and how to report a fault or issue with the PPE. Managers must ensure that their employees have received this training and provide appropriate supervision to ensure that employees are using PPE correctly. Training can be conducted in multiples ways for example a short face to face session, an instructional booklet or eLearning depending on the requirement.

_items.title: Assess Suitability
_items.body: Does the PPE protect the wearer from the risks and take account of the environmental conditions? For example, eye protection designed to protect against liquids may not offer adequate protection when using an angle grinder.

_items.title: Overall Risk
_items.body: Those with management responsibilities should consider if the PPE increases the overall level of risk or add new risks, for example by making communication more difficult?

_items.title: User Demands
_items.body: What are the needs of the job and the demands it places on the wearer? For example, how long will the PPE need to be worn, what physical effort is required and what are the requirements for visibility and communication? Can the PPE be adjusted to fit the wearer correctly?

_items.title: Multiple Items
_items.body: If someone in your employees wears more than one item of PPE, are they compatible? For example, does using a respirator make it difficult to fit eye protection properly?

_items.title: Storage
_items.body: Personal protective equipment must be well looked after and properly stored when it is not being used. For example, in a dry, clean cupboard, or a box or case for smaller items.

_items.title: Maintenance
_items.body:
Equipment should be kept clean and in good repair, following the manufacturer’s maintenance schedule (including recommended replacement periods and shelf lives). Always ensure suitable replacement PPE is readily available for your employees.

Respiratory protective equipment may require face fit testing and the health and safety team can provide guidance if required.

title: Possible Hazards & Types of PPE
instruction: Select each card to see possible hazards & types of PPE

_items.body:
Hazards
Chemical or metal splash, dust, projectiles, gas and vapour, radiation.

Options
Safety goggles, face-shields, visors.

Additional information
Ensure eye protection has the right combination of impact/dust/ splash/molten metal eye protection for the task and fits the user properly.

Hazards
Impact from falling or flying objects, risk of head bumping, hair entanglement.

Options
Helmets, hard hats and bump caps. Some safety helmets incorporate or can be fitted with specially-designed eye or hearing protection. Neck protection should also be considered.

Additional information
Do not use head protection if it is damaged – replace it.

Hazards
Dust, vapour, gas, oxygen-deficient atmospheres.

Options
Disposable filtering face-piece or respirator, half- or full-face respirators, air fed helmets, breathing apparatus.

Additional information
The right type of respirator filter must be used for different substances. Where there is a shortage of oxygen or any danger of losing consciousness, only use breathing apparatus. All respirator filters or similar apparatus must be used, maintained and replaced in accordance with manufacturers’ guidance.

Hazards
Temperature extremes, adverse weather, chemical or metal splash, spray from pressure leaks or spray guns, impact or penetration, contaminated dust, excessive wear or entanglement of own clothing.

Options
Conventional or disposable overalls, boiler suits, specialist protective clothing e.g. chain-mail aprons, high-visibility clothing.

Additional information
The choice of materials includes flame-retardant, anti-static, chain mail, chemically impermeable, and high-visibility.

Hazards
Abrasion, temperature extremes, cuts and punctures, impact, chemicals, electric shock, skin infection, disease or contamination.

Options
Gloves, gauntlets, mitts, wrist-cuffs, armlets.

Additional information
Separate cotton inner gloves can help prevent skin problems. Avoid gloves when operating machines such as bench drills, where the gloves could get caught. Be aware that some people may be allergic to materials used in gloves e.g. latex.

Hazards
Wet, electrostatic build-up, slipping, cuts and punctures, falling objects, metal and chemical splash, abrasion.

Options
Safety boots and shoes with protective toe caps and penetration-resistant mid-sole, gaiters, leggings, spats.

Additional information
Footwear options include oil or chemical-resistant, anti-static, electrically conductive or thermally insulating soles.

title: Signage

_items.body:
Safety signs include the use of illuminated signs, hand and acoustic signals (e.g. fire alarms), spoken communication and the marking of pipe work containing dangerous substances. Safety signs play an important part in communicating health and safety information to everyone. Signs need to be provided whenever there’s a hazard that hasn’t been fully controlled in other ways. Make sure your employees understand the meaning of the signs.

Consider members of your employees with vision or hearing impairments.

_graphic.label: Why do we need safety signage?

White circle with red edging and a diagonal line. This prohibits behaviour likely to increase or cause danger.

Mandatory

Warning

A triangular sign with black edging and a yellow background indicates warning of a hazard and would normally contain a black pictogram.

Safety Information

Green signs identify or locate safety equipment as well as marking emergency escape routes.

title: Introduction
body:
Completing risk assessments and implementing control measures should reduce the risks from hazards in the workplace, but mistakes and errors can still occur resulting in injuries, ill health or damage.

Those with management responsibilities need to know what to do on these occasions, how to learn from them and if required who to contact for further guidance and assistance.

title: Reducing Injury
body:
Fires injure and kill people through:
  • Heat and flames
  • Smoke, which can suffocate or poison them
  • Collapse of buildings.

Once a fire’s started, the best way to reduce injury or death is to get people away from it and out of reach of the smoke. However, the best approach is to prevent fires starting in the first place. A fire will only go out when there’s no oxygen, the fuel runs out or the heat is removed by cooling with water or another firefighting measure.

title: How does a fire start?
body: Workplace fires cause many people to suffer from burns each year and some prove fatal. The following is a re-cap on fire safety, you can find further training on the fire safety eLearning package.
instruction: Play the video to see how a fire starts

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Fires need three things to start...
A source of ignition, or heat...
A source of fuel, or something that burns...
...and oxygen.
Ignition sources can include heaters, lights, naked flames, electrical equipment, cigarettes and matches, and anything else that gets very hot or cause sparks.
Sources of fuel include wood, paper, plastic, rubber or foam, packaging materials, waste rubbish and furniture.
And of course, oxygen is in the air all around us.
In order to get started, every fire needs all three things.

title: Fire Safety
body:
Within all main offices fire safety is normally managed by the fire teams however as a manager, you’ll need to make sure that fire risks in the areas you and your employees work are managed effectively including in other employer’s properties.

As a manager, think about:
How much training you and your employees have had in fire safety?
What fire precautions are in place, such as smoke detectors, fire alarms, escape routes and firefighting equipment?
What are the emergency procedures for the areas you and your employees work in?
Have your employees been provided with fire safety training and guidance on the emergency procedures and evacuation plan?
Have you thought about emergency situations, when entrance and exit routes might change?
Is there fire risk assessment in place?
Is there a requirement for a Personal Emergency Evacuation Plan (PEEP) for any of your employees?

There will be more fire related information contained within the intranet platforms you use including contact details for more guidance from the appropriate employees.

title: Emergency Procedures
body: In the event of an emergency you need to consider what might happen and how the alarm will be raised. During your planning remember to include night and shift workers, weekends and times when the premises are closed, such as holidays.
instruction: Select each heading to learn more about emergency procedures.

_items.title: Emergency Evacuations
_items.body:
Ensure there are enough emergency exits for everyone to escape quickly, and keep emergency doors and escape routes unobstructed and clearly marked.

You must train everyone in emergency procedures, remembering to consider the needs of people with disabilities and vulnerable workers.

Decide where to go to reach a place of safety or to get rescue equipment and ensure there is suitable emergency lighting.

_items.title: Competent Person
_items.body:
Nominate a competent person to take control in the event of an emergency (someone with the necessary skills, knowledge and experience to manage health and safety).

Next, decide which other key people you need, such as a nominated incident controller, who is able to provide technical and other site-specific information if necessary, or first-aiders.

_items.title: Emergency Services
_items.body:
Plan what to do, including how to call the emergency services if you are working outside of the UK please make international considerations to you plan.

Help them by clearly marking your premises from the road and consider drawing up a simple plan showing the location of hazardous items.

If you have 25 tonnes or more of a dangerous substance, you must notify the fire and rescue service and put up warning signs.

title: First Aid
body:
People at work can sustain an injury or become ill, and it’s important they receive immediate attention and an ambulance is called in serious situations.

The provision of adequate first aid cover is essential, as it can save lives and prevent minor injuries becoming major ones. An assessment must be conducted in order to assess the first aid requirements in your office to help you decide on the equipment and facilities you need. Notices are also required to tell your employees where they can find nominated first aiders and the first aid box.

title: First Aid – Management Responsibilities
body:
Within main offices during normal working hours first aid provision is available. However, those with management responsibilities need to satisfy themselves that adequate first aid resource is available at all times for their employees including lone workers.

As a manager are you and your employees certain of how to summon first aid assistance at all times?

Lots of information is available to you on local intranet systems regarding first aid to assist you however the health and safety team are available to provide guidance when required.

title: Accidents and Incidents
body:
Risk assessments and implementing control measures should reduce the risks from potential hazards, but mistakes can still occur resulting in injuries or ill health.

It is important you understand the various terms and definitions used to describe injuries or ill health in the workplace.
instruction: Select each heading to learn more.

_items.title: Accident
_items.body: An undesired event that results in injury or occupational disease.

_items.title: Incident
_items.body: An event that causes damage to property or machinery, but no injuries or ill health have occurred.

_items.title: Near Miss
_items.body: An event or condition that doesn’t cause harm but has the potential to do so.

_items.title: Undesired Circumstance
_items.body: A set of conditions or circumstances that have the potential to cause injury or ill health.

_items.title: Dangerous Occurrence
_items.body: One of a number of specific, reportable adverse events, as defined in the Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR).

_items.title: Damage
_items.body: An undesired event that results in property damage.

title: Investigations
body:
There are a number of reasons to investigate accidents and incidents, including:
  • To collect the information you need to pass on to the enforcing authority such as the HSE
  • To identify the cause of the accident and/or incident to stop it happening again
  • To get information needed for a claim
  • To find out the cost of an accident.

title: Investigations – Good Practice
body:
It’s good practice to carry out an investigation to find out how and why the accident and/or incident happened so that you can stop it happening again. It’s also important to do this with an open mind. An investigation provides a snapshot of how tasks are really done – it may not be how you think it’s done – and helps you to find out any shortcomings in the risk controls.

The key benefits of investigation are to:
  • Make a safer work environment
  • Improve employees morale
  • Prevent losses from disruption and down-time
  • Prevent more accidents and/or incidents

title: Investigations – Remember!
body:
Near misses that don’t result in any loss, such as an injury or damage to equipment, also need to be reported and investigated. This is because these incidents could cause injury or loss next time they happen.
As an example, a painter working on a platform might drop a tool, which falls to the ground, causing nothing more than the inconvenience of having to and get it later. On the other hand, the tool might hit another worker or member of the public, causing a serious head injury.

title: Reporting the accident or incident
body:
Those with management responsibility must ensure their employees report (as soon as possible) after the accident or incident directly to them.
As a manger you must ensure the internal reporting process is adhered to this ensures the health and safety team are made aware and can provide guidance and support when required.

title: Who carries out the investigation?
body:
Carrying out an accident or incident investigation may need a range of knowledge, skills and experience. Those with management responsibility should lead the investigation owing to their authority and knowledge to make authoritative recommendations.

But depending on the severity of the injury or potential severity of the incident those with management responsibility may be asked to involve various stakeholders to form a team and could include:
  • Employees familiar with the work location
  • A supervisor or manager from the work location
  • A senior manager with authority or influence
  • A health and safety team member
  • An employee representative
  • A person involved in the accident or incident (if possible)
  • A technical expert e.g. engineering or medical, if necessary.

title: Legal Duty
body:
Your Organisation has a legal duty to record and report all accidents and incidents in our workplaces this includes notifying the HSE in certain circumstances.
All reporting to the HSE is managed through your health and safety team and ensures our legal obligations under Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR) are satisfied.
Additionally, the requirement for completing RIDDOR reports for third parties working with us or on our property are completed by the health and safety team. This requirement must be formally explained to your contact.

title: Monitoring
body:
Monitoring the effectiveness of the control measures in your workplace is essential.

Monitoring could include the following: Checking compliance to relevant local health and safety policies or procedures, reviewing control measures stated within risk assessments, inspecting workplace locations and activities, checking competence of employees and contractors and checking the wellbeing and health of employees.

As a manager, it's important to ensure regular inspections take place in proportion to the risk profile of the working area - for example; safety critical areas such as loading bays, workshops and catering facilities should be checked on a frequent basis to ensure there are no physical hazards, fire hazards, or other shortcomings that could affect the health and safety of employees.

title: Monitoring
body:
In lower risk office environments, periodic inspections should also take place for items such as workstation equipment, electrical cables, traffic routes and general housekeeping to identify any hazards and prevent accidents from occurring.

Any inspection made by a manager or other employee should be recorded, and any hazards identified should be removed, reduced or re-risk assessed to ensure they are managed to prevent reasonably foreseeable incidents from occurring.

title: Monitoring
body:
Inspections are an important part of health and safety monitoring and they help to provide risk assurance information to the business.

Are you aware of any formal inspections that are conducted within your area? If there are no formal inspections being performed then good practice would be to determine a planned programme of monitoring. Contact your health and safety team to assist in the development of such programmes

These type of 'area based' workplace inspections are in addition to any statutory or insurance inspections that apply to equipment and machinery subject to regulatory requirements.

title: Introduction
body:
Manual handling covers a number of activities, such as lifting, lowering, carrying, pushing and pulling. These activities can cause musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) – such as lower back pain, joint injuries and repetitive strain injuries.

Manual handling injuries are a common cause of workplace injury and occur across a range of tasks from logistics, construction activities to office work.

title: Reduce the Risk
body:
Measures to control risk will vary depending on the task. Where possible, you should provide and use mechanical help, but if this is not reasonably practicable, explore changes to the task, the load and the working environment.

As a manager there are four main things you and your employees should consider when assessing the risk of manual handling:

_items.title: Reduce the Load
_items.body:
• Could the weight, size and shape of the load increase the risk of injury – for example, is it hard to grip? What needs to change to improve this factor?
  • Loads which are small and easy to grasp are generally less of a risk than large, awkwardly shaped loads.
  • Generally, the heavier the load, the higher the risk of injury from moving it.
.

Select each heading to learn more.

_items.title: Modify the Environment
_items.body:
• Look at the surroundings where the handling job is to take place.
  • Could the environment increase the risk of injury – for example, are there objects in the way or uneven surfaces? What needs to change to improve this factor?
  • Anything which makes the manual handling more difficult increases the risk of injury, such as uneven floors or carrying loads from one level to another.

_items.title: Task
_items.body: Could manual handling aspects of the task increase the risk of injury – for example, twisting or reaching while lifting? What needs to change to improve this factor? Carrying out a manual handling operation more than 30 times per hour increases the risk of injury. The higher, lower or further employees have to reach to pick up or put down the load, the higher the risk.

_items.title: Individual
_items.body: • What is it about the person that makes this task more or less safe? Could some personal characteristics increase the risk of an injury – for example, has the person had training, or do they have any history of back problems? What needs to change to improve this factor? If employees have to lift or move something whilst in an awkward posture, or while seated, the risks of injury are greater.

title: Preventing Injury
body:
Those with management responsibilities should minimise manual handling tasks as far as possible, however where it is not possible to avoid handling a load, consider the risks of the task and put sensible health and safety measures in place to prevent and avoid injury.

Measures to control risk will vary depending on the task. Where possible, you should provide and use mechanical help, but if this is not reasonably practicable, explore changes to the task, the load and the working environment.

An additional manual handling eLearning training package has been devised by the health and safety team and ensures managers and employees are competent to perform manual handling duties.

Ensure you and your employees access the internal eLearning to assist in ensuring tasks are performed as safely as possible.

title: New and Expectant Mothers
body:
Pregnancy is not an illness and whilst it is important to realise that new and expectant mothers will naturally experience new challenges, it is also known that their health can be affected by workplace factors.

The organisation is committed to protecting the health and safety of all new and expectant mothers.
instruction: Select each title to view more information about your responsibilities to new and expectant mothers.

_items.title: Manager Responsibilities
_items.body:
When informed by an employee that they are a new or expectant mother, you should complete a corporate New and Expectant Mother Risk Assessment Form.

Ensure the findings of the risk assessment are communicated fully to the employee and review the risk assessment at least once per trimester and on the mother’s return to work.

_items.title: The Risks
_items.body:
You should consider the risks that may arise from any process, working condition, or physical, biological or chemical agents.

Some of the more common risks are:
  • lifting or carrying heavy loads
  • standing or sitting for long periods
  • exposure to infectious diseases
  • exposure to lead
  • work-related stress
  • workstations and posture
  • exposure to radioactive material or toxic chemicals
  • long working hours
  • excessively noisy workplaces


If any reasonably foreseeable risks are identified, you must take appropriate action as soon as you are notified, in writing, that an employee is a new or expectant mother, to ensure she is not further exposed.

_items.title: Unavoidable Risks
_items.body:
If you are unable to avoid or control any risks that go beyond the level of risk found outside the workplace, then you must take appropriate action.

This might include altering working conditions and/or hours of work or finding suitable alternative work.

Support and guidance can be obtained from occupational health and health and safety teams.

title: Home Workers
body:
Employers are required to protect the health, safety and welfare of homeworkers. If you employ homeworkers you should carry out a risk assessment of their work activities and take appropriate measures to reduce any associated risks.

Most work carried out at home is going to be low-risk, office-type work and may require DSE training, DSE assessment and the suitability of the home accommodation determined. Your organisation has policy and procedures in place for this type of working so please access your internet for further guidance.

title: Managing Home Workers
body:
If your employees work at home, doing activities outside of low-risk office type work such as working with adhesives, soldering, manufacturing, using power tools, etc. Please contact your health and safety team for further guidance and support.

Managers will need to consider the particular risks involved in these activities. For example, you need to check that any equipment you supply to them is in good condition, lone working has been considered and that they have the correct personal protective equipment (PPE) if required.
